instruction: What metric was chosen to discriminate different kinds of ginsengs in the hybrid system combining an electronic nose system (E-nose), and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to discriminate different kinds of ginsengs in the hybrid system combining an electronic nose system (E-nose) is classification accuracy. The classification accuracy measures the percentage of correctly classified samples out of the total number of samples. In the related case, the hybrid system achieved an optimal classification accuracy of 99.58% with weighted feature-level fusion and 99.24% with decision-level fusion.

The classification accuracy metric provides a measure of how well the hybrid system is able to correctly classify the different kinds of ginsengs. A classification accuracy of 99.58% means that the hybrid system was able to accurately classify 99.58% of the samples correctly. This indicates a high level of accuracy and reliability in the classification process.

instruction: What approaches were explored for data-fusion in the hybrid system combining an electronic nose system (E-nose) with a sensor array of 16 metal-oxide sensors and a near-infrared reflectance spectroscopy (NIRS) system to discriminate different kinds of ginsengs?
Output: Two approaches were explored for data-fusion in the hybrid system combining an electronic nose system (E-nose) with a sensor array of 16 metal-oxide sensors and a near-infrared reflectance spectroscopy (NIRS) system to discriminate different kinds of ginsengs. These approaches were weighted feature-level fusion and decision-level fusion.

instruction: Can the hybrid system using an electronic nose system (E-nose) and near-infrared reflectance spectroscopy (NIRS) be considered superior to traditional methods in discriminating different kinds of ginsengs, based on the optimal classification accuracy achieved and the statistical significance confirmed in the study?
Output: Yes, the hybrid system using an electronic nose system (E-nose) and near-infrared reflectance spectroscopy (NIRS) can be considered superior to traditional methods in discriminating different kinds of ginsengs. This is based on the optimal classification accuracy achieved by the hybrid system (99.58% with weighted feature-level fusion and 99.24% with decision-level fusion), which significantly outperformed the performance of individual systems (90.18% by the E-nose and 97.98% by NIRS). The statistical significance of this improvement was confirmed by the Student's t-test (p < 0.001).
